paragraphs.title: Getting information about a Dataframe
paragraphs.text:
%spark

import org.apache.spark.sql.types.{StructField, StructType, StringType, LongType}

val dataSchema = new StructType(Array(
    new StructField("DEST_COUNTRY_NAME", StringType, true),
    new StructField("ORIGIN_COUNTRY_NAME", StringType, true),
    new StructField("count", LongType, false)
))

val flightDf = spark.read.format("csv").option("header", "true").option("mode", "FAILFAST").schema(dataSchema).load("../../../../Data/2010-summary.csv")
    
flightDf.cache

flightDf.columns

flightDf.explain

flightDf.dtypes

flightDf.printSchema

flightDf.show

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Language-integrated query methods of the DataFrame class

We will create some dataframes programmatically to illustrate the language integrated query methods.

msg.data:
Language-integrated query methods of the DataFrame class

We will create some dataframes programmatically to illustrate the language integrated query methods.

paragraphs.text:
%spark

case class Customer(cId: Long, name: String, age: Int, gender: String)
val customers = List(
    Customer(1, "James", 21, "M"),
    Customer(2, "Liz", 25, "F"),
    Customer(3, "John", 31, "M"),
    Customer(4, "Jennifer", 45, "F"),
    Customer(5, "Robert", 41, "M"),
    Customer(6, "Sandra", 45, "F")
)
val customerDF = sc.parallelize(customers).toDF()

case class Product(pId: Long, name: String, price: Double, cost: Double)

val products = List(
    Product(1, "Dell", 600, 400),
    Product(2, "Kindle", 100, 40),
    Product(3, "iPad", 600, 500),
    Product(4, "Galaxy", 600, 400),
    Product(5, "MacBook", 1200, 900),
    Product(6, "iPhone", 500, 400)
)
val productDF = sc.parallelize(products).toDF()

case class SalesSummary(date: String, product: String, country: String, revenue: Double)

val sales = List(SalesSummary("01/01/2015", "Chromebook", "USA", 40000),
SalesSummary("01/02/2015", "Chromebook", "USA", 30000),
SalesSummary("01/01/2015", "Chromebook", "India", 10000),
SalesSummary("01/02/2015", "Chromebook", "India", 5000),
SalesSummary("01/01/2015", "Macbook", "USA", 20000),
SalesSummary("01/02/2015", "Macbook", "USA", 10000),
SalesSummary("01/01/2015", "Macbook", "India", 9000),
SalesSummary("01/02/2015", "Macbook", "India", 6000))

val salesDF = sc.parallelize(sales).toDF()

productDF: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [pId: bigint, name: string ... 2 more fields]
defined class SalesSummary

salesDF: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [date: string, product: string ... 2 more fields]

paragraphs.text:
%md

## agg

The **agg** method performs specified aggregations on one or more columns in the source DataFrame and
returns the result as a new DataFrame.

msg.data:
agg

The agg method performs specified aggregations on one or more columns in the source DataFrame and
returns the result as a new DataFrame.

paragraphs.text:
%spark

val aggregates = productDF.agg(max("price"), min("price"), count("name"))

aggregates.show

%md

## apply

The **apply** method takes the name of a column as an argument and returns the specified column in the
source DataFrame as an instance of the **Column** class. The **Column** class provides operators for manipulating a
column in a DataFrame.

msg.data:
apply

The apply method takes the name of a column as an argument and returns the specified column in the
source DataFrame as an instance of the Column class. The Column class provides operators for manipulating a
column in a DataFrame.

paragraphs.text:
%spark

val priceColumn = productDF.apply("price")

val discountedPriceColumn = priceColumn * 0.10

%md

Scala provides syntactic sugar that allows you to use productDF("price") instead of productDF.apply("price"). 

It automatically converts productDF("price") to productDF.apply("price"). 

So the preceding code can be rewritten as follows:

msg.data:
Scala provides syntactic sugar that allows you to use productDF(“price”) instead of productDF.apply(“price”).

It automatically converts productDF(“price”) to productDF.apply(“price”).

So the preceding code can be rewritten as follows:

paragraphs.text:
%spark

val priceColumn = productDF("price")

val discountedPriceColumn = priceColumn * 0.5

%md

## Notes on the **Column** class

An instance of the **Column** class is generally used as an input to some of the DataFrame methods or functions defined in the Spark SQL library.

If a method or function expects an instance of the Column class as an argument, we can use the **$"..."** notation to select a column in a DataFrame.

For example, the following three aggregates are equivalent:

msg.data:
Notes on the Column class

An instance of the Column class is generally used as an input to some of the DataFrame methods or functions defined in the Spark SQL library.

If a method or function expects an instance of the Column class as an argument, we can use the $“…“ notation to select a column in a DataFrame.

For example, the following three aggregates are equivalent:

paragraphs.text:
%spark

val aggregates1 = productDF.agg(max(productDF("price")), min(productDF("price")), count(productDF("name")))

aggregates1.show

val aggregates2 = productDF.agg(max("price"), min("price"), count("name"))

aggregates2.show

val aggregates3 = productDF.agg(max($"price"), min($"price"), count($"name"))

aggregates3.show

%md

### **select**

The *select* method returns a DataFrame containing only the specified columns from the source DataFrame.

msg.data:
select

The select method returns a DataFrame containing only the specified columns from the source DataFrame.

namesAgeDF: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [name: string, age: int]
+--------+---+
|    name|age|
+--------+---+
|   James| 21|
|     Liz| 25|
|    John| 31|
|Jennifer| 45|
|  Robert| 41|
|  Sandra| 45|
+--------+---+

paragraphs.text:
%md

### **filter**

The filter method filters rows in the source DataFrame using a SQL expression provided to it as an argument. It returns a new DataFrame containing only the filtered rows. The SQL expression can be passed as a string argument.

msg.data:
filter

The filter method filters rows in the source DataFrame using a SQL expression provided to it as an argument. It returns a new DataFrame containing only the filtered rows. The SQL expression can be passed as a string argument.

paragraphs.text:
%spark

val filteredDF = customerDF.filter("age > 25")

filteredDF.show

val filteredDF2 = customerDF.filter($"age" > 40)

filteredDF2.show

val filteredDF3 = customerDF.filter(customerDF("age") > 20)

filteredDF3.show

paragraphs.text:
%md

### **groupBy**

The *groupBy* method groups the rows in the source DataFrame using the columns provided to it as arguments. Aggregation can be performed on the grouped data returned by this method.

msg.data:
groupBy

The groupBy method groups the rows in the source DataFrame using the columns provided to it as arguments. Aggregation can be performed on the grouped data returned by this method.

paragraphs.text:
%spark

val countByGender = customerDF.groupBy("gender").count

countByGender.show

val revenueByProductDF = salesDF.groupBy("product").sum("revenue")

revenueByProductDF.show

%md

### **orderBy**

The *orderBy* method returns a DataFrame sorted by the given columns. It takes the names of one or more columns as arguments.

msg.data:
orderBy

The orderBy method returns a DataFrame sorted by the given columns. It takes the names of one or more columns as arguments.
